College of Materials Science and Engineering Qiqihar University Qiqihar 161006 China The key to generating hydrogen by electrolysis of water is to design the low-cost and high-catalytic activity catalyst. In this paper, FeNi-Layered Double Hydroxide@L-NCP/nickel foam (FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF) is prepared using leaf-like zeolitic imidazolate framework (L-Co-ZIF) as the precursor, phosphating to produce NiCoP (denoted as L-NCP) and then growing FeNi layered double hydroxide (FeNi-LDH) through a hydrothermal crystallization method. FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF is an exceptional catalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) as well as oxygen evolution reaction (OER). It shows the low overpotential of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF and the values are 106 and 220 mV at 10 mA·cm-2 in 1 M KOH for HER and OER, respectively. This is because the more ordered L-NCP is formed due to the role of the ZIF templates, which favors rapid charge transfer between the electrolyte and the electrode, thereby promoting its catalytic performance. The synergistic effect of FeNi-LDH and L-NCP also contributes to activity. Graphical abstract In this paper, The FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF catalyst is obtained through a hybrid strategy by loading FeNi-LDH prepared via hydrothermal method onto the prepared MOF-derived L-NCP. Both NiCoP nanosheets grown vertically on NF and FeNi-LDH graded nanosheets can supply significant abundant active sites for HER and OER. The unique double-layer structure of FeNi-LDH and the network structure of L-NCP constitute a unique three-dimensional interface, which constitutes an efficient mass transfer channel and promotes charge transfer to further improve conductivity. Image, graphical abstract Keywords HER OER Layered double hydroxide ZIF-derived Transition metal phosphides Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction The development of renewable energy sources has prioritized for resolving the global energy crisis and environmental pollution. Generating "green hydrogen" by electrolyzing water has become a promising renewable energy solution owing to its stability, efficient water decomposition, and zero harmful by-products [ 1-3 ]. Usually, two types of catalysts are required to provide a low overpotential for the HER and OER processes [4],[5]. The most representative catalysts currently are precious metal-based catalysts, for example, Pt catalysts with high activity in HER, and Ru and Ir catalysts with high performance and stability in the OER [ 6-8 ] The non-renewable and expensive nature of precious metals limits their industrial applications. Based on it, researchers have committed to developing catalysts with low cost and high performance. Transition metal catalysts are widely used in HER and OER reactions, especially transition metal oxides [ 9-11 ], sulfide [ 12-14 ], phosphorides [ 15-17 ], layered double hydroxide (LDH) [18 , 19], and metal-organic frameworks (MOF) [20 , 21]. LDHs are viable alternatives to precious metal catalysts on account of their unique two-dimensional layered structure and bimetallic synergy. Among the many layered bimetallic hydroxide catalysts, FeNi-LDH is an alkaline OER electrocatalysts with outstanding performance [ 22-25 ]. They found that this was due to the oxidation of NiFe-LDH to Ni1-xFexOOH (x<25%) during the OER process, which transformed into a Fe-doped-NiOOH structure. At the same time, the DFT calculation also proved that this structure led to the OER intermediate close to the optimal adsorption energy, and had a positive effect on the OER [26]. Nevertheless, due to the weak binding ability of Fe3+ to hydrogen, the kinetic energy barrier of the Volmer step is large, resulting in slow HER kinetics [27]. In recent years, transition metal phosphide (TMP) has been broadly applied as efficient HER catalyst for electrocatalysis. In the process of hydrogen evolution, phosphorus can increase the adsorption rate from the active site to the reaction intermediate and promote charge transfer between the transition metal and the phosphorus atoms. DFT calculation proved that the P atom provided appropriate bonding for the reaction intermediates, and the equilibrium of hydrogen adsorption and desorption on the phosphide surface was more helpful to HER [28]. However, because of the limited porosity of bimetallic TMP, a metal-organic framework (MOF) can be used to develop highly porous structures to facilitate gas diffusion to improve HER activity [ 29-32 ]. Gao et al. [33] used accordion-like Co-MOF as the precursor, N and P co-doped Co/CoP with heterostructure HER catalyst (Co/CoP@PNC) synthesized by carbonization and phosphatization had an overpotential of 137 mV at 10 mA·cm-2 in 1.0 M KOH. Wang et al. [34] studied the activity and stability of porous 3D MOF-derived N-CoPx/Ni2P electrode at high current density for HER. According to DFT calculations, it was found that the unique 3D self-supporting porous structure contributed to the exposure of abundant active sites and promoted the release of H2, and the synergistic interaction between CoP and Ni2P could effectually optimize the adsorption energy of hydrogen intermediates, thereby improving HER performance. Consequently, enhancing HER activity of NiFe-LDH while preserving its OER performance is crucial for developing an exceptional bifunctional catalyst for electrocatalytic water splitting. Hybrid engineering constitutes an efficacious methodology for improving the performance characteristics of materials. By combining two materials to produce synergistic effects, the overall catalytic activity can be improved [ 35-37 ]. Choi et al. [38] combined cobalt phosphide (CoP) derived from MOF with Co-Fe LDH on conductive carbon cloth to prepare a layered electrocatalyst CoP@Co-Fe LDH. It was found that the activity of the combined composite could outperform that of CoP and Co-Fe LDH, which proved that the electrocatalytic performance was improved. Yang et al. [39] synthesized a non-precious metal electrocatalyst, NiCoP@FeNi-LDH/NF, for hydrogen production via hydrothermal phosphating electrodeposition way. The overall water decomposition just needed 1.70 V battery voltage at 1000 mA·cm-2. Here, we propose a hybrid strategy to prepare the FeNi-Layered Double Hydroxide @L-NCP/nickel foam (FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF) catalyst by growing FeNi-LDH onto the prepared MOF-derived L-NCP via hydrothermal method. Both NiCoP nanosheets grown vertically on NF and FeNi-LDH graded nanosheets can supply abundant active sites for HER and OER. The unique double-layer structure of FeNi-LDH and the network structure of L-NCP constitute a unique three-dimensional interface, which constitutes an efficient mass transfer channel and promotes charge transfer to further improve conductivity. 2 Experiment 2.1 Experimental materials NF was purchased from the China Cyber Electrochemical Materials Network. KOH (≥85%, A.R.), NaH2PO2 (≥95%, A.R.), urea (CH4N2O, ≥99%, A.R.), ammonium fluoride (NH4F, ≥96%, A.R.), dimethylimidazole (C5H8N2, ≥98%, A.R.), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (≥99%, A.R.), Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (≥99%, A.R.), and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (≥98%, A.R.) were purchased from Aladdin. 2.2 Catalyst Preparation The electrocatalysts were synthesized according to Scheme 1 , and the procedure is outlined in the subsequent section. 2.2.1 Preparation of the L-Co-ZIF/NF Initially, the foam nickel underwent pretreatment utilizing acetone solution and 2 mol/L HCl to eliminate organic matter and the oxidation layer present on the surface. Next, 50 mL of deionized water and 0.582 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O formed solution A. 50 mL of deionized water and 1.314 g of C5H8N2 resulted in solution B. Solution A was poured into solution B, and the mixed solution immediately turned purple. Finally, NF was deposited in a purple solution at room temperature for 5 h to obtain L-Co-ZIF/NF. For L-Co-ZIF/NF in this article, the loading was ca. 1.8 mg·cm-2. 2.2.2 Preparation of L-NCP/NF 1 g of NaH2PO2 and the above obtained L-Co-ZIF/NF were placed at the front and back ends of the tube furnace, respectively, and L-NCP/NF was obtained by calcination for 2h at 350 °C under N2 atmosphere. For L-NCP/NF in this article, the loading was ca. 1.8 mg·cm-2. 2.2.3 Preparation of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF composite electrocatalyst was prepared using an in situ growth strategy. 0.25 mmol Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and 0.75 mmol Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 1.25 mmol urea, 1.25 mmol ammonium fluoride, and 40 mL H2O were mixed, and then the mixed solution was stirred for 30 min. Finally, L-NCP/NF was placed into the above solution and crystallized at 120 °C for 10 h, after which the solid product was cleaned several times using H2O and EtOH. The sample was dried at 60 °C to obtain FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF. In contrast, FeNi-LDH/NF was prepared without L-NCP/NF under the same method, which is based on the literature with some modifications [40]. For FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF in this article, the loading was ca. 2.0 mg·cm−2. 2.3 Characterization The catalyst morphology was examined utilizing scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S-3400, Japan). XRD (BRUKER-AXS, Germany) was employed to elucidate the structure. For qualitative and valence analysis of the elements, XPS was conducted using the Thermo, ESCALAB250Xi (USA) instrument. 2.4 Electrochemical testing For all electrochemical tests, Chenhua electrochemical workstation (CHI600C) was used. We utilized a three-electrode system with a Hg/HgO electrode as the reference electrode, a graphite carbon rod as the counter electrode, and the preparation of materials (measuring 1 cm × 1 cm) as the working electrode. HER and OER activity tests were conducted in a 1mol/L KOH solution. Before electrochemical hydrogen or oxygen evolution tests, the electrolyte was purged with nitrogen for 30 min to eliminate air. Prior to electrochemical testing, cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed 30 times at a scanning rate of 50 mV·s-1 to activate the working electrode and stabilize the electrode surface. Electrode potentials are compared to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), in this process, the Nernst equation (ERHE=EHg/HgO+0.098 V+0.059 pH) is used to convert the testing voltage into the voltage required for the RHE. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) sweep rate was set to 5 mV·s-1, and the current density was adjusted with 90% iR compensation. Tafel slope was determined via equation (1). (1) η = a + blogj where η, b, and j represent overpotential, Tafel slope, and current density, respectively. The non-Faradaic potential range was selected, and cyclic voltammetry (CV) was conducted with scan rates ranging from 10 to 100 mV·s-1. Then, the difference in the current density (△J) corresponding to the intermediate potential of the tested potential window was calculated, and then the corresponding scanning rate and △J were plotted, followed by linear fitting. The obtained slope of the straight line was double Cdl value (Cdl is double-layer capacitance), The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) can be obtained using equation (2) (2) ECSA = C dl / C s Where Cs represents the capacitance of a smooth flat surface of a unit area material under specific electrolyte conditions and is equal to 0.040 mF·cm-2. All materials were subjected to electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) testing under specific conditions, which involved an open circuit potential and a frequency range of 105 to 10-2 Hz. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and morphology characterization The XRD of bare NF, L-Co-ZIF/NF, L-NCP/NF, FeNi-LDH/NF, and FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF are depicted in Fig 1 . Three diffraction peaks centered at 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4° are characteristic of NF (JCPDS No. 04-0850), and the typical diffraction peaks of L-Co-ZIF/NF are consistent with the literature [41]. The peaks of NiCoP/NF at 2θ=41.0°, 47.5°, and 54.4° correspond to the (111), (210), and (300) planes of L-NCP. Additionally, FeNi-LDH/NF peaks at 2θ=11.7°, 23.3°, 34.6°, 39.0°, and 61.3° correspond to (003), (006), (012), (015), and (113) planes of FeNi-LDH (JCPDS No.51-0463). More than anything, the typical diffraction peaks of L-NCP and FeNi-LDH were observed for the FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF. The SEM images of various catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . It is obvious from Fig. 2a that the surface of L-Co-ZIF/NF was relatively smooth, exhibiting a blade-layered structure, and the grain morphology was hexagonal with uniform size. After the subsequent phosphating process, the L-NCP/NF material inherited the polyhedral morphology of L-Co-ZIF, and a partial L-NCP/NF formed a three-dimensional stacking structure (Fig. 2b). In addition, it is apparent from Fig. 2 (c-d) that the shape of FeNi-LDH/NF is spherical at a magnification of 4000 times. After magnification, FeNi-LDH/NF still presents a lamella-like structure and grows vertically on the nickel foam. It is evident from Fig. 2 (e-f) that the morphology of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF was nanocluster, consisting of many smooth and uniform lamellar nanosheets with a particle size of ca. 200 nm. The wrinkled morphology of FeNi-LDH growth on the L-NCP surface can increase its specific surface area, which is more advantageous for the exposure of active sites. SEM mapping confirms the uniformity of Ni, Co, Fe, P, and O elemental distributions in the material (Fig. 3 ). TEM and HRTEM are used to further study the morphology and interface between the L-NCP nanowires and the FeNi-LDH nanosheets. The surface of the FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF composite is smooth and has an obvious layered structure (Fig. 4 a). The existence and concentration of five elements, Fe, Co, Ni, O, and P, are verified by EDS (Fig. S1). Fig. 4 (b-d) proves that the FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF material exhibits a heterogeneous structure, with ultrathin FeNi-LDH/NF nanosheets surrounding the surface of L-NCP/NF, and the lattice spacing at different material interfaces corresponds to the XRD plane. The uniform distribution of Fe, Co, Ni, O, and P is further demonstrated by elemental mapping (Fig. 4e-j). The compositions and valence states of the catalyst were analyzed by XPS. It can be concluded from Fig. 5 a that Co, Ni, O, and P were present in L-NCP/NF. Additionally, XPS demonstrated the presence of Co, Ni, Fe, O, and P in FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF. For L-NCP/NF, there exist two peaks with binding energies of 781.6 eV and 797.5 eV, which correspond to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively, suggesting that Co2+ is presented. Characteristic peaks centered at 781.9 eV and 797.2 eV are observed for FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF, ascribing to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 autorotation orbits of Co2+. The Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 peaks of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF show shifts of 0.32 eV and 0.28 eV, respectively, compared to L-NCP/NF, owing to charge transfer between FeNi-LDH and L-NCP/NF (Fig. 5b). In Fe XPS spectrum (Fig. S2), the peaks appeared at 710.8 eV and 719.9 eV are assigned to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2, respectively. FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF is thought to have the distinctive characteristics of Fe3+. According to Fig. 5c, the binding energies of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF at 855.8 eV and 861.7 eV of Ni2+ correspond to Ni 2p3/2 and its satellite peaks, respectively. Characteristic peaks at 873.6 eV and 879.4 eV are ascribed to Ni 2p1/2 and its satellite peaks, respectively. For L-NCP/NF, Ni2+ peaks at 855.6 eV and 873.6 eV appear. Notably, the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 peaks of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF show shifts of 0.19 eV and 0.52 eV, respectively, compared to L-NCP/NF. It is also noticeable that the main peaks at 132.8 eV and 133.6 eV correspond to PO4 3- of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF and L-NCP/NF, respectively, which can be ascribed to the generation of the P-O bonds when the electrocatalyst is exposed to air (Fig. 5d). And the most amazing thing is that the binding energies of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF and L-NCP/NF at 129.9 eV and 129.2 eV are less than 130.0 eV (element P), affirming the presence of metal phosphate [42]. Meanwhile, the P 2p peak of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF shifts to the lower binding energy and is moved by 0.82 eV, once more verification of enhancing charge transfer between L-NCP and FeNi-LDH boosts the kinetics of HER and OER reactions [43]. 3.2 Electrochemical testing 3.2.1 HER electrocatalytic test The HER performances of NF, L-Co-ZIF/NF, FeNi-LDH/NF, L-NCP/NF, and FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF are displayed in Fig. 6 . FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF exhibits an overpotential of 106 mV at 10 mA·cm-2 (Fig. 6a). Notably, the overpotential of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF is significantly less than those of L-NCP/NF (172 mV), L-Co-ZIF/NF (199 mV), FeNi-LDH/NF (247 mV) and pure foam nickel (285 mV). Additionally, an overpotential of the reported Pt/C was 36 mV for the HER reaction [44]. In addition, FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF had a lower overpotential than that reported in the literature (Table S1). Next, the speed of the kinetics of materials in the HER catalytic process is further evaluated by the Tafel curve. As illustrated in Fig. 6b, the Tafel slopes of NF, FeNi-LDH/NF, L-Co-ZIF/NF, and L-NCP/NF are 265.2, 110, and 109.2, 99.3 mV·dec-1 respectively. The Tafel slope is a parameter used to determine the rate-determining step in electrochemical reactions. The Tafel slope less than 30 mV·dec-1 indicates that the Tafel step is the rate-determining step, while a slope greater than 120 mV·dec-1 illustrates that the Volmer step is the rate-determining step. However, if the slope is between 40 and 120 mV·dec-1, then the Heyrovsky step is the rate-limiting step [45]. However, the Tafel slope of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF is 58.5 mV·dec-1, which approximates the lower limit of the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism (40 mV·dec-1), suggesting that the HER process of the FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF follows the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism, thereby demonstrating enhanced HER kinetics. The number of active sites on the NF substrate is a critical factor influencing the performance. As a consequence, ECSA of the prepared electrodes was measured via CV (Fig. S2) and is shown in Fig. 6c. According to the open circuit voltage, the volt-ampere curve of the foam nickel-loaded catalyst electrode at different scanning rates in the voltage interval of 0.5 V∼0.6 V. The corresponding scanning rate at a voltage of 0.55 V and △J were plotted. It becomes clear from Fig. 6c that the difference in current density is linearly related to the scanning rate under a given potential. The Cdl values of the electrodes were obtained by fitting. The Cdl values of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF, NF, FeNi-LDH, L-Co-ZIF/NF and L-NCP/NF are 29.6, 4.4, 10.2, 16.9 and 17.9 mF·cm-2, respectively. A Higher Cdl value implies more active sites and higher ECSA, which is also an important reason for the higher hydrogen evolution performance of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF electrodes. By further comparing the electron transmission rate of different catalysts in the HER process through EIS testing, the diameter of the arc in the test curve is related to its electron transfer impedance. Small diameters show smaller impedance and faster electron transfer rates. As shown in Fig. 6d, FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF exhibits the smallest impedance characteristic (Rct=0.14 Ω), which is smaller than that of NF (Rct=4.38 Ω), FeNi-LDH/NF (Rct=1.37 Ω), L-Co-ZIF/NF (Rct=0.87 Ω) and L-NCP/NF (Rct=0.38 Ω). The results indicate that the electron transfer process of the FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF electrode is faster than that of NF, FeNi-LDH/NF, L-Co-ZIF/NF, and L-NCP/NF, indicating that FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF has good electrical conductivity. The stability of an electrocatalyst is crucial for its practical application. In this study, stability was assessed using conducting chronopotentiometry at a constant current density of 10 mA·cm-2 for a period of 48 h, and the current density retention rate is 97.5% (Fig. 6e). Additionally, Fig. 6f shows that the FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF has remarkable durability in an alkaline solution. It maintained stability even after 1000 cycles. 3.2.2 OER electrocatalytic test LSV was used to measure the polarization curve of the electrode to evaluate its OER activity, as depicted in Fig. 7 a. FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF showed superior OER performance with an overpotential of 220 mV, which is inferior to those of L-NCP/NF (η10=246 mV), L-Co-ZIF/NF (η10=287 mV), FeNi-LDH/NF (η10=275 mV), and bare NF (η10=398 mV). Overpotential of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF is inferior to that of the reported RuO2/NF (η10=251 mV) electrode[46]. In addition, the Tafel slope is a key parameter for evaluating the OER mechanism at the electrolyte and electrolyte interface. It represents the change rate of overpotential with increasing current density, and the lower value belongs to the faster reaction intrinsic kinetics and better electrocatalytic performance [47 , 48]. As can be seen from Fig. 7b, the Tafel slope of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF (72.5 mV·dec-1) falls well below that of L-Co-ZIF/NF (240.3 mV·dec-1), FeNi-LDH/NF (89.5 mV·dec-1), L-NCP/NF (85.2 mV·dec-1) and NF (285.3 mV·dec-1). FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF demonstrated a lower overpotential and Tafel slope in alkaline electrolytes compared to other reported electrocatalysts (Table S2). This indicates that the FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF electrocatalyst exhibits superior OER catalytic performance and faster OER reaction kinetics. Additionally, the effect of ECSA on the OER activity was evaluated via testing the Cdl of the electrode using CV (Fig. S3) at various scanning rates. Fig. 7c shows that the Cdl values of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF, L-NCP/NF, L-Co-ZIF/NF, FeNi-LDH/NF, NF are 34.5, 31.3, 23.4, 3.8 1.5 mF·cm-2, respectively. It is clear that FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF has a larger ECSA, indicating that the formation of heterogeneous interfaces between L-NCP and FeNi-LDH facilitates a rise in the number of active sites, thereby improving catalytic performance. In the OER, the rate of charge transfer is a critical factor that influences the kinetic performance of the electrocatalysis. The kinetics of the catalyst electrode reactions can be effectively studied through EIS testing. Based on this, the prepared materials were tested by EIS, and the results are depicted in Fig. 7d, the Rct value of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF is 0.06 Ω, which is not bigger than L-Co-ZIF/NF (Rct=0.28 Ω), NiFe-LDH/NF (Rct=2.49 Ω), L-NCP/NF (Rct=0.11 Ω) and bare NF (Rct=6.4 Ω). This indicates that the more ordered L-NCP is formed due to the role of ZIF templates, which is beneficial to rapid charge transfer between the electrolyte and the electrode, thereby promoting its OER performance. This aligned with the results of the LSV curves and Tafel slopes. As shown in Fig. 7e, a durability test lasting up to 48 h was carried out at 10 mA·cm-2. The current density retention rate is 98.2%. The time-current curve shows that the current density does not decay significantly with the extension of time, signifying that the material maintains superior stability. In addition, the LSV curve shows no significant change after 1000 CV tests (Fig. 7f), indicating that the FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF electrocatalyst has good cyclic stability and electrocatalytic activity. For the purpose of studying the composition, morphology and structure of the representative FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF catalyst after the stability test for HER and OER reaction, XRD, XPS and SEM of the representative FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF catalyst after the stability test for HER and OER reaction are performed. As displayed in Fig. S5, the peaks of the nickel foam after the stability testing are more significant, but other peaks are not obvious. For XPS of Co 2p, Ni 2p, Fe 2p (Fig. S6), the area of all characteristic peaks is relatively reduced, which may be related to the shedding of a part of the material on the catalyst surface during the reaction. The peak of P 2p at the low binding energy disappears, indicating that the formed metal oxides/hydroxides are predominant on the surface of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF during HER and OER tests. It is evident from Fig. S7 and S8 that the FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF samples after long-term stability tests show a rough, flat-layered structure, which is attributed to the fact that part of the morphology generated by the surface shedding of catalyst materials is similar to that in Fanne-LDH /NF. However, some agglomerations occur, which is the main reason for the decrease of performance. These results confirm a slight change of the structure and morphology of the catalyst after the HER and OER tests. According to the aforementioned data, acting as both cathode and anode in water electrolysis, FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF operates as a bifunctional electrocatalyst with remarkable HER and OER catalytic activity. FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF (+, -) necessitates 1.57 V to achieve 10 mA·cm-2 in the electrolytic cell (Fig. S9). The following Table 1 is a comparison of the overall water splitting performance between our designed FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF and the reported bifunctional catalysts [49 - 53], illustrating that FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF exhibits preferable activity for overall water splitting. Moreover, the current retention rate is 97.8% after 24 h cycle for overall water splitting and the current density shows little variation as time increase (Fig. S10), signifying that the FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF has outstanding stability. 4 Conclusion FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF was controllable and prepared using in situ growth of L-Co-ZIF on NF as a sacrificial template, and its electrocatalytic performance is investigated for HER and OER reactions. It exhibits remarkable performance and durability for HER, achieving a minimal overpotential of 106 mV and displaying a Tafel slope of 58.5 mV·dec-¹ at 10 mA·cm-² in 1 M KOH electrolyte. For OER, it likewise displays superior electrocatalytic performance with an overpotential of 220 mV and a Tafel slope value of 72.5 mV·dec-¹ under identical alkaline conditions, while maintaining durability. Combined with the XPS results, the charge transfer between L-NCP and FeNi-LDH could improve the reaction kinetics of the HER and OER. This may also be due to the existence of a more ordered L-NCP at the expense of the ZIF templates. In addition, FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF exhibited superior cycling stability in the HER and OER in 1 M KOH. This study offers fresh perspectives for the development of hydrogen production. CRediT authorship contribution statement Boxuan Zhang: Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: The key to generating hydrogen by electrolysis of water is to design the low-cost and high-catalytic activity catalyst. In this paper, FeNi-Layered Double Hydroxide@L-NCP/nickel foam (FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF) is prepared using leaf-like zeolitic imidazolate framework (L-Co-ZIF) as the precursor, phosphating to produce NiCoP (denoted as L-NCP) and then growing FeNi layered double hydroxide (FeNi-LDH) through a hydrothermal crystallization method. FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF is an exceptional catalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) as well as oxygen evolution reaction (OER). It shows the low overpotential of FeNi-LDH@L-NCP/NF and the values are 106 and 220 mV at 10 mA·cm-2 in 1 M KOH for HER and OER, respectively. This is because the more ordered L-NCP is formed due to the role of the ZIF templates, which favors rapid charge transfer between the electrolyte and the electrode, thereby promoting its catalytic performance. The synergistic effect of FeNi-LDH and L-NCP also contributes to activity.

coredata.dc:title: Fabrication of excellent bifunctional electrocatalyst FeNi-LDH@L-NiCoP using ZIF as a sacrifice template for alkaline electrolysis of water
